Description: Rim and neck sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black with added red bands (mostly worn); on top of rim, an incised palmette and lotus band (mostly worn); on edge: short stepped zigzag pattern; underside of rim painted with double brown band; black neck.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd NA165 joins Reading 26.2.90 and Boston 86.631 and may also belong to the same vase as Alexandria 9488. The vase is probably by a painter in the Three Maidens Group (Early-Middle Corinthian). For the drawing of the floral elements and the proportion of lotus to palmette, see the Basle krater (private collection) (Benson 1956, pl. 75, figs 34-35), which Benson (1969, 120, no. B 1a) attributes to the manner of the Memnon Painter. The sherd Louvre E 630 (Payne 1931, 154, fig. 62c; NC 1181D) is attributed by Benson (1969, 120, D2) to the Detroit Painter. Benson, J. L. 'Some Notes on Corinthian Vase-Painters', American Journal of Archaeology 60.3, Jul. 1956, 219-230 Benson, J. L. 'The Three Maidens Group', American Journal of Archaeology 73.2, Apr. 1969, 109-122 The Boston sherd was found in the region of the Sanctuary of Apollo.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p.102-3, no. A155)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.014) (Phase 1)
